audio_caption: The audio begins with lively, upbeat jazz music, featuring instruments like piano and drums. A male speaker then begins, introducing a series of videos about physical chemistry 2, with a tone that's welcoming and educational. He explains the focus on quantum mechanics, specifically the study of the energy and motion of particles. Background music continues quietly as the speaker continues. He explains how classical mechanics was insufficient to explain observations.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing a phenomenon that puzzled physicists in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Then, a second male speaker introduces Albert Einstein, asks if he ever received a Nobel Prize, confirms that he did, and asks what theory led to the prize.

A male speaker begins by stating that if you said the theory of relativity, you're wrong about that. He continues by explaining that Einstein's most famous work is the theory of relativity, but he also worked on other physics problems like capillary action and how particles move in a fluid. He says that his theory of the photoelectric effect is what he won the Nobel Prize for. The speaker then says that the idea is simple, and asks what the photoelectric effect is.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker explaining Heinrich Hertz's discovery of the photoelectric effect in 1887, mentioning Hertz's connection to frequency measurements. The speaker discusses how shining ultraviolet light on an electrode produces electrical sparks by knocking off electrons from the metal. The tone is informative and explanatory. The speech is accompanied by a static background sound that seems constant throughout.  The speaker adds a remark about the unexpected behavior of the photoelectric effect when conducting experiments.

The audio clip features a single male speaker, who adopts an explanatory and slightly conversational tone, discussing how scientists once thought light waves would affect electrons similarly to sound waves. He mentions how increasing the amplitude of light waves by making the light brighter doesn't change the speed of the electrons, but rather increases their number. He further explains how changing the frequency of the light wave changes the electrons' energy, contrary to what was expected. Throughout his explanation, a consistent, low-volume ticking sound plays in the background, creating a subtle sense of rhythm.

The audio clip begins with a single male speaker describing two surprising results. In a calm, factual tone, he explains that increasing light intensity increases the number of electrons but not their speed, while increasing frequency does cause them to move faster. Using the analogy of waves on a beach, he elucidates the counterintuitive nature of the results. The speaker questions why this is the case and concludes by stating it was one of Einstein's biggest successes.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker explaining Albert Einstein's ideas about light and photons, adopting a clear, informative tone. He describes how brighter light means emitting more photons and their impact on electrons, further elaborating on how light's color relates to its energy and its frequency. He continues by explaining the equation related to this concept. Throughout the speech, there's a distinct rhythmic ticking sound in the background, providing a consistent backdrop.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker who states, "know it at the time" and continues to describe the usefulness of the photoelectric effect. He highlights its importance in solar energy, particularly how "a lot of solar cells" use it to convert "sunlight into electricity." The speaker then mentions its use in night vision glasses, where "infrared light" triggers an electrical current.

The clip begins with a single male speaker discussing Einstein's idea that light can behave as a particle, referring to it as a "photon." He mentions scientists like Isaac Newton who previously thought of light as made of particles they called "corpuscles." His tone is informative and engaging. He then transitions to discussing Einstein's idea, stating that it was a "big step in the creation of quantum mechanics," and poses the question of "what is light then?".

The audio clip begins with a male speaker who sounds enthusiastic and informative. He announces that in their next discussion, he will be discussing "one of the most fundamental ideas in all of modern physics and chemistry: the relationship between particles and waves." He notes that the two things are closely related and that they will deal with the "consequences of that for all the rest of this course." He invites the listener to join him and wishes them a good week. Afterwards, a short instrumental music piece begins, featuring a banjo or similar stringed instrument. The music has a happy and upbeat tone.
